text: There hath no temptation taken you but such as is common to man: but God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation also make a way to escape, that ye may be able to bear it.
text_kjv: There hath no temptation taken you but such as is common to man: but God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation also make a way to escape, that ye may be able to bear it.
text_niv: No temptation has seized you except what is common to man. And God is faithful; he will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear. But when you are tempted, he will also provide a way out so that you can stand up under it.
text_esv: No temptation has overtaken you that is not common to man. God is faithful, and he will not let you be tempted beyond your ability, but with the temptation he will also provide the way of escape, that you may be able to endure it.
text_nlt: The temptations in your life are no different from what others experience. And God is faithful. He will not allow the temptation to be more than you can stand. When you are tempted, he will show you a way out so that you can endure.
text_msg: No test or temptation that comes your way is beyond the course of what others have had to face. All you need to remember is that God will never let you down; he'll never let you be pushed past your limit; he'll always be there to help you come through it.
text_nasb: No temptation has overtaken you but such as is common to man; and God is faithful, who will not allow you to be tempted beyond what you are able, but with the temptation will provide the way of escape also, so that you will be able to endure it.
context: First Corinthians was written by the Apostle Paul to the church in Corinth, a bustling port city in ancient Greece known for its diverse population, wealth, and moral laxity. The Corinthian church faced numerous challenges, including divisions, sexual immorality, idolatry, and misunderstandings about spiritual gifts and the resurrection. Chapter 10 specifically addresses the issue of idolatry and participation in pagan feasts, a temptation particularly prevalent in Corinthian society. The city was filled with temples dedicated to various gods, and social life often revolved around religious festivals and banquets where meat sacrificed to idols was consumed. Paul's warning about repeating the sins of the Israelites in the wilderness (verses 1-12) serves as a cautionary tale. The Israelites, despite witnessing God's miraculous deliverance, succumbed to idolatry and other sins. Paul uses this example to highlight the danger of complacency and the need for constant vigilance against temptation, particularly in a culture steeped in pagan practices. Verse 13, therefore, provides assurance and hope in the midst of this challenging environment, promising God's faithfulness and provision in the face of temptation. Understanding the cultural context of Corinth, with its pervasive idolatry and moral ambiguities, is crucial for grasping the full weight and significance of Paul's message in this verse.
meaning: 1 Corinthians 10:13 offers a powerful message of hope and assurance for believers facing temptation. The phrase "there hath no temptation taken you but such as is common to man" emphasizes the universality of temptation. It reminds us that we are not alone in our struggles; others have faced similar challenges throughout history. The word 'temptation' encompasses not just enticement to sin, but also trials and hardships that test our faith. The core of the verse lies in the affirmation of God's faithfulness. Paul declares that "God is faithful," a crucial aspect of God's character demonstrated throughout Scripture. This faithfulness means that God remains true to His promises and His love for us. He will not allow us to be tempted beyond our ability to resist, a limit set not by our own strength, but by His grace and provision. The phrase "will with the temptation also make a way to escape" is pivotal. God doesn't just passively watch us struggle; He actively provides a path to freedom from temptation. This "way of escape" may manifest in various forms: inner strength, wise counsel, changed circumstances, or opportunities to remove ourselves from the situation. The final clause, "that ye may be able to bear it," underscores the purpose of the escape route. It is not merely to avoid discomfort, but to empower us to endure the temptation and grow in spiritual maturity. God's provision is not about removing all challenges, but about equipping us to overcome them, fostering resilience and deepening our reliance on Him.
application: 1 Corinthians 10:13 provides practical guidance for navigating temptation in the modern world. First, recognize the commonality of temptation. Social media, consumerism, career pressures, and relationship challenges all present unique temptations, but the underlying desires and vulnerabilities are universally human. Knowing that others struggle with similar issues can reduce feelings of isolation and shame. Second, actively rely on God's faithfulness. Cultivate a daily practice of prayer and Bible study to strengthen your relationship with Him. When faced with temptation, consciously turn to God for guidance and strength, trusting in His promises. Third, seek and utilize the "way of escape." This requires discernment and intentionality. Identify potential triggers and develop strategies to avoid them. This might involve setting boundaries on social media usage, seeking accountability partners, or changing environments that expose you to temptation. For example, if you struggle with overspending, create a budget, unsubscribe from tempting marketing emails, and avoid shopping malls. If you battle with anger, identify the root causes and develop coping mechanisms like deep breathing, exercise, or seeking counseling. Fourth, embrace the opportunity for growth. View temptation not just as a threat, but also as a chance to develop resilience and spiritual maturity. Every time you successfully resist temptation, you strengthen your character and deepen your dependence on God. Fifth, extend grace to yourself and others. Recognize that failure is part of the learning process. When you stumble, don't give up. Seek forgiveness, learn from your mistakes, and continue to press on. Also, extend compassion and understanding to others who are struggling, remembering that we are all vulnerable to temptation and in need of God's grace.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I thank you for the assurance of your faithfulness, especially in the face of temptation. I acknowledge that I am not immune to temptation, and I often struggle with my weaknesses. Help me to recognize that I am not alone in these battles, and that you have promised to never leave me nor forsake me. I ask for your wisdom and guidance to identify the specific temptations I face and the ways of escape you provide. Strengthen my resolve to resist temptation and to choose your path of righteousness. Grant me the grace to learn from my failures and to extend compassion to others who are struggling. May your Holy Spirit empower me to live a life that honors you, even in the midst of challenging circumstances. Thank you for your unwavering love and provision. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: No, this verse does not imply God predetermines specific temptations. It means God, in His foreknowledge, knows what we can handle and provides a way out when temptation arises. He sets a limit, ensuring we are not overwhelmed.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does this verse mean God predetermines our temptations?

faqs.answer: A 'way to escape' signifies God's active provision for resisting temptation. This can be inner strength, changing circumstances, wise counsel, or the opportunity to physically remove oneself from the tempting situation.
faqs.question: Q2: What does 'a way to escape' really mean?

faqs.answer: While God provides a way out, our free will allows us to choose whether to take it. We often fall because we resist God's guidance, underestimate the power of temptation, or rely on our own strength instead of His.
faqs.question: Q3: If God provides a way out, why do I still fall into temptation?

faqs.answer: Yes, the principle applies to every temptation. God promises to provide a way out and to limit the temptation to what you can bear with His help. Actively seeking Him is the key to recognizing and utilizing that escape.
faqs.question: Q4: Does this verse apply to every single temptation I face?

faqs.answer: Even when feeling overwhelmed, remember God's faithfulness. Cry out to Him for strength, seek support from other believers, and examine if there are any practical steps you have not taken to avoid the temptation.
faqs.question: Q5: What if I feel overwhelmed and that the temptation IS too much to bear?
